Award.AwardTitle: Deformation Mechanics and Microstructure Evolution During Microforming of Metals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to study the mechanics of metal deformation during microextrusion and their effect on the resulting grain structures. The experimental approach will utilize an optically transparent micro-scale extrusion die to directly visualize material behavior in a prototypical microforming configuration. By utilizing advanced high speed image processing techniques in combination with thermography, direct insights into the spatio-temporal variation of the deformation mechanics will be obtained. This characterization will be coupled with quantitative electron microscopy to elucidate the mechanisms by which plastic strains in microforming are accommodated by the evolving grain structure. The resulting process-structure mappings are expected provide the empirical data to help reliably model, predict and manipulate process and product outcomes in microforming.

If successful, the results are critical to a better understanding of the mechanics of microforming systems and of importance to the manufacturing and fabrication of advanced microsystems. The results of the research can be applied to a wide variety of engineering sectors including electromechanical, biomedical and defense manufacturing industries where the reliability of metallic microcomponents can determine the product life and performance. This grant will also support a cross-disciplinary, research-integrated education program targeted at the undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral levels by sparking collaborative initiatives between the Medical Center and the School of Engineering at the University of Pittsburgh.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to measure in process, the mechanics and the temperatures in the deformation zone in forming-based manufacturing processes in sub-mm scale samples. This study made available for the first time, a direct and comprehensive characterization of how the material deforms in the deformation zone and the interplay of the mechanics with the temperature field during metal forming at reduced length-scales. This identified microstructure-based models of the microforming process and pin-pointed the mechanisms that lead to failures. This knowledge-base can transform microforming process-designs to achieve tailored property combinations in microsystems through microstructure design and control. 

The results offer directions for designing  microstructural characteristics that result in tailored properties and process outcomes -- a capability that can impact an array of engineering sectors, including the microelectronics, defense and the biomedical industries. The results also enabled microstructure-based computational analysis of microforming and refine existing material-model based computational routines. This is now possible  because, the computational models can be compared to a dynamic, in situ (in-process) measurement of the strain, strain-rate, temperature and microstructure fields, especially for the technologically important but heretofore poorly understood case of microforming. Prior to this work, the experimental studies offered at best, a post-deformation, ex situ scheme entirely devoid of the dynamic details of the deformation field and microstructure evolution characteristics. Thus, not only preventing any direct one-to-one validation of simulation models but also, not offering any in-depth insights into the interplay of the central variables of micro-scale metal forming. 

In accomplishing these measurements, we also developed a suite of new experimental tools, which allow for observing the deformation of materials simultaneosly using visible light and infra red. Image processing algorithms developed for this study enable the characterization of the mechanics across length-scales ranging from the macro to the micro-scale. We also built a new system, which essentially converts the sample chamber of a scanning electron microscope into a miniaturized metal-forming system. This allowed us to probe the mechanics of micro-scale sheet-metal forming and glean insights into how the crystal structure deforms, where the defects and process failures originate and how do they propagate.
